awd_abstract_narration: The technique of X-ray crystallography is a powerful tool for                   the determination of the molecular structure of compounds as                    diverse as small polypeptides and complex metal clusters.  When                 combined with the latest computer software, the technique is                    becoming remarkably easy to put into practice.  Access to X-ray                 crystallographic instrumentation markedly improves the ability                  of chemists to carry out frontier research.                                                                                                                     The Department of Chemistry at the University of California,                    San Diego, will use this award from the Chemical                                Instrumentation Program to help acquire an X-ray                                diffractometer.   The areas of chemical research that will be                   enhanced by the acquisition include the following:                                                                                                              1) Structural elucidation of marine natural products                            2) X-ray diffraction of peptides                                                3) Structural aspects of electron transfer processes                            4) Metallo-organic molecules as mediators and models                            5) Transmission of stereochemical information                                   6) Structure of metallo-enzyme mimics.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
